Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes, my mother’s name lighting up the screen. I could almost hear her gentle voice, asking if I’d eaten, if I was sleeping enough, if I’d remembered to water my plants. We talked every day, and she expected me to share everything—my worries, my triumphs, even the mundane details. But right now, I was sitting across from Mr. Lee, a patient whose autoimmune disease had flared up again. He needed me to focus, to review his complex chart, to adjust his medications with precision. My pager beeped, and my mother’s message popped up: “Are you okay? Haven’t heard from you today.” Guilt twisted in my chest. I wanted to reassure her, to be the attentive daughter she counted on. But Mr. Lee’s anxious eyes were on me, waiting for answers only I could give. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore.
